column21: In my opinion one of key problems of promoting AI for biosciences is the lack of trust on that systems. Therefore, I believe that one key activity for promoting discussions is to present AI tools as collaborative methods, intended to function in conjunction with human involvement rather than operating autonomously. By adopting this approach, the seamless integration of such technologies into daily practices becomes more attainable,  promoting  discussion about them.

column9:
We have a central HPC with 624 cores, 3.3 TB of shared RAM, and 20 TB of High Throughput storage. A secondary HPC consists of 96 cores, 512 GB of RAM, connected with our storage devices, and is used mainly for sandbox testing without occupying the central cluster’s resources.
We use a server consisting of 40 Intel(R) Xeon(R) Silver 4210R CPU @ 2.40GHz cores for standalone operations.
We use a GPU machine with the Intel(R) Core (TM) i7-8700K CPU @ 3.70GHz processor and two NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1080 Ti GPUs, and a second GPU machine with Intel(R) Core (TM) i7-9700 CPU @ 3.00GHz processor and one NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Ti GPU.

column20: It depends on the level/the type of engagement and the area of application. It is a combination of multiple fields: Computer Science, Data Analysis, Data Engineering, Graph Theory, Information Theory,  Linear Algebra, Operations Research, Signal Processing, Statistics. And these are just the foundation. If we consider the applications e.g. Life Sciences, the required list of skills expands more. And of course, the ability to follow the rapidly changing literature and developments of a highly competitive field.
column21: There are many things that can be done but the most important one is to form a specialized community that is actively engaged and overly dedicated the topic. I think these twο initial steps are important: 1) Trying to reach experts with high relevance operating in academia and industry that have left the country. 2) Identifying which labs and companies are active in the Greece.
